title: 105_s620
content: The "Women's Investment and Savings Equity Act of 1997" allows individuals to make deductible IRA contributions without considering their spouse's participation in a pension plan. Additionally, individuals are permitted to make contributions during periods of maternity or paternity leave. The amendment to Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals in their plan or arrangement. This provision impacts the qualification of trusts under various sections of the Code. The amendment to Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals in their plan or arrangement without limitations under various sections of the Code. The amendment allows participants on eligible maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals in their plan without limitations under specific sections of the Code. The amendment permits additional elective deferrals during eligible maternity or paternity leave without restrictions under certain sections of the Code, including matching contributions with separate application of section 401(a)(4) requirements and a limit on the contribution amount. The amendment allows for elective deferrals during eligible maternity or paternity leave, with a limit on contribution amounts and matching contributions not exceeding what could have been made under the plan if the deferral had been made during the leave period. During eligible maternity or paternity leave, elective deferrals can be made within a 3-year period after the leave ends, with adjustments for deferrals actually made. Matching contributions are also allowed, not exceeding what could have been contributed during the leave period. During eligible maternity or paternity leave, an employee can make elective deferrals within a 3-year period after the leave ends. Matching contributions must be made by the employer's tax return due date. Eligible leave includes absence due to pregnancy, childbirth, or child placement. During eligible maternity or paternity leave, an employee can make elective deferrals for up to 12 months following the birth or placement of a child. The term 'elective deferral' includes after-tax employee contributions. The term 'elective deferral' includes after-tax employee contributions and applies to arrangements under section 408(k) or (p). Certain retroactive adjustments are not required, and loan repayment suspensions are permitted during eligible maternity and paternity leave. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 1997. Catchup contributions are allowed for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals under the plan or arrangement. This includes specific provisions for trusts, plans, and arrangements under the Internal Revenue Code. The plan must allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals in certified catchup years, with limitations on the amount of deferrals permitted. The participant may make additional elective deferrals in certified catchup years, limited by 120 percent of the applicable dollar limitation for the calendar year, minus any other elective deferrals made without regard to this subsection. Contributions to the plan are treated accordingly. In certified catch-up years, additional elective deferrals by the participant are limited to 120% of the applicable dollar limitation for the year, minus any other deferrals made without regard to this subsection. Contributions to the plan are subject to specific treatment, exempt from certain limitations and not counted towards other contributions or benefits under the plan. In certified catch-up years, additional elective deferrals by the participant are limited to 120% of the applicable dollar limitation for the year. Contributions to the plan are exempt from certain limitations and not counted towards other contributions or benefits under the plan. Matching contributions are not required but if made, must meet specific requirements. The employer is not required to make matching contributions for additional elective deferrals, but if they choose to do so, certain conditions must be met. The participant must certify to the plan administrator when making additional elective deferrals in a catch-up year. A participant making additional elective deferrals in a catch-up year must certify to the plan administrator that they are eligible and that the year is a catch-up year. The participant can certify multiple years as catch-up years, up to a limit based on the number of years described in the plan. The plan administrator must certify the number of years a participant can make catch-up contributions, not exceeding 18 years. Plans are not at fault for certification errors unless the administrator knew or should have known about the mistake. Eligible participants are those in the plan who certify a catch-up year. The plan administrator is only at fault for certification errors if they knew or should have known about the mistake. An eligible participant is defined as someone in the plan who certifies a catch-up year and meets specific criteria regarding active participation and having a child under 18. The amendment made by this section applies to contributions in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997. Definitions for elective deferral, plan, and retroactive adjustments are provided for this subsection.
